concession.translation[0].definitions[0]: something that you allow someone to have in order to end an argument or a disagreement
The British were not prepared to make any concessions.
The committee has won a number of major concessions from the prison authorities.
a policy of no concessions to terrorists
his readiness to make concessions on many of the issues raised
We will try to force further concessions from the government.
concession.translation[0].definitions[1]: a special right that a particular person or group of people is allowed to have, for example by the government or an employer, or the act of giving or allowing something as a right
the ending of tax concessions for home owners
the import/export concessions that had been granted to the island
the concession of autonomy to the universities
concession.translation[0].definitions[2]: a reduction in the price of tickets, fees etc for certain groups of people, for example old people or children
To qualify for travel concessions you have to be 60.
Open daily, adults £4, concessions £2 (=people who have the right to a concession pay £2).
concession.translation[0].definitions[3]: a change in your behaviour that you make because of a particular situation or idea
He took off his jacket as a concession to the heat.
He made no concessions to fashion.
concession.translation[0].definitions[4]: the right to have a business in a particular place, especially in a place owned by someone else
The company owns valuable logging and mining concessions.
concession.translation[0].definitions[5]: a small business that sells things in a place owned by someone else
Joe runs a hamburger concession in the mall.
concession.translation[0].note_box[0].se: The government made some concessions in order to satisfy the rebels.
The King was prepared to offer some concessions to France.
In the end, the strikers returned to work having won few concessions.
The Indian government was able to extract concessions on the price of oil.
We made some major concessions in order to protect national security.
Israel refused to give up Sinai without some significant concession on Egypt's part.
Washington made a few minor concessions in the climate talks.
They refused any further concessions in the argument over agricultural exports.
In the past they have tried to exchange territorial concessions for peace.
concession.translation[1].definitions[0]: the right to carry out a particular business activity, given or sold to a company by a government or other public organization
BellSouth paid B$2.65 billion for the concession to operate cellular phones in São Paulo.
The company was granted a concession to build a 364 km stretch of the Warsaw-to-Berlin motorway.
concession.translation[1].definitions[1]: a small shop in a hotel, theatre, office building etc owned and managed by another business
Snack concession sales per person at cinemas have increased.
concession.translation[1].definitions[2]: an agreement or rule allowing someone to pay less money, tax etc than they would normally pay
American Express offered a rate concession to Laura Ashley’s UK operations.
The tax concessions apply only after the savings account has been held for five years.
concession.translation[1].definitions[3]: the amount paid to an UNDERWRITER when new shares or bonds are made available for the first time
a public offering of 8 million common shares, priced at $16 a share through underwriters Morgan Stanley - selling concession is 61 cents
